column1: Linguist A. P. Nepokupnyj proposes that the language source for Białystok is Yotvingian. Names with the -stok suffix as a second element of a hydronym are localized in the basin of the upper Narew.

Archaeological discoveries show that the first settlements in the area of present-day Białystok occurred during the Stone Age. Tombs of ancient settlers can be found in the district of Dojlidy. In the early Iron Age
column2: people settled in the area producing kurgans
column3: the tombs of the chiefs in the area located in the current village of Rostołty. Since then
column4: the Białystok area has been at the crossroads of cultures. Trade routes linking the Baltic to the Black Sea favored the development of settlements with Yotvingia-Ruthenian-Polish cultural characteristics.The city of Białystok has existed for five centuries and during this time the fate of the city has been affected by various political and economic forces.

The Dojlidy Ponds recreation area includes a public beach

column1: The city has a mild-summer continental or hemiboreal climate (Dfb) according to the Köppen climate classification system
column2: characterized by warm temperatures during summer and long and frosty winters. It is substantially different from most of the other Polish lowlands. The region is one of the coldest in Poland
column3: with the average temperature in January being −3.7 °C (25 °F). The average temperature in a year is about 7 °C (45 °F). The number of frost days ranges from 50 to 60
column4: with frost from 110 to 138 days and the duration of snow cover from 90 to 110 days. Mean annual rainfall values oscillate around 567 mm (22.3 in)
column5: and the vegetation period lasts 200 to 210 days.

column2: and a number of venues where they are based. Jagiellonia Białystok is a Polish football club
column3: based in Białystok
column4: in the Ekstraklasa (Poland's top division) that plays at the Białystok City Stadium. Jagiellonia Białystok won the Polish Cup in 2010
column5: Super Cup and qualified to play in the third round qualification of the UEFA Europa League. A new 22
column6: 500 seat stadium was completed at the beginning of 2015.Hetman Białystok (formerly known as Gwardia Białystok) is a Polish football club based in Podlaskie Voivodeship. They play in the Division IV or the (4th) League.Lowlanders Białystok is a football club
column7: based in Białystok
column8: that plays in the Polish American Football League (Polish: Polska Liga Futbolu Amerykańskiego)  PLFA I Conference. The Lowlanders were the champions of the PLFA II Conference in 2010 with a perfect season (8 wins in eight meetings). Because of the win they were advanced to the upper conference (PLFA I) in 2011.

column1: Białystok has a wide variety of media outlets serving the city and surrounding region. There are two locally published daily newspapers
column2: Gazeta Współczesna  (36.3% market share)  and Kurier Poranny (20.3% market share). In addition two national papers have local bureaus. There are a number of national and locally produced television and radio channels available both over-the-air from the nearby RTCN Białystok (Krynice) Mast
column3: the seventh highest structure in Poland
column4: in addition to transmitter sites within the city. TVP Białystok is one of the locally produced
column6: Poland's public television broadcaster. There is also a cable television system available within the city. The city has two campus radio stations; Radiosupeł at the Medical University of Białystok and Radio Akadera at  Białystok Technical University.

column2: Białystok was reputed to have the largest concentration of Jews of all the cities in the world. In 1931
column4: 000 Jews lived in the city

column1: The city is the seat of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Białystok. Pope John Paul II on 5 June 1991
column2: during a visit to Białystok
column3: announced the establishment of the Archdiocese of Białystok which ended the period of the temporary church administration of the portion of the Archdiocese of Vilnius that had
column4: after World War II
column5: remained within the Polish borders. The city is also the seat of the Białystok-Gdansk Diocese of the Autocephalous Polish Orthodox Church. Białystok is the largest concentration of Orthodox believers in Poland. In Białystok
column6: the following Protestant churches exist: a Lutheran parish
column7: two Pentecostal churches
column8: Baptist church
column9: a congregation of the Church of God in Christ and a Seventh Day Adventist church.Białystok is home to more than two thousand Muslims (mainly Tatars). There is an Islamic Centre
column11: and various organisations. There is magazine issued – "Pamięć i trwanie" ("Memory and persistence").

column1: The city is the site of the Divine Mercy Sanctuary with the main relics of Michał Sopoćko.
The city is and has been for centuries
column2: the main hub of transportation for the Podlaskie Voivodeship and the entire northeastern section of Poland. It is a major city on the European Union roadways (Via Baltica) and railways (Rail Baltica) to the Baltic Republics and Finland. It is also a main gateway of trade with Belarus due to its proximity to the border and its current and longstanding relationship with Hrodna
column3: Belarus.

column1: A traffic management system has been operating in Białystok since 2015. At 120 intersections
column2: traffic lights are coordinated in such a way that cars and buses covered the route as quickly as possible. Special cameras record traffic
column3: travel time. Drivers receive this information on 19 boards set among others at the intersections on Wasilkowska Street
column4: Antoniuk-Fabryczny Street and Kleeberga Street.

column2: Grodno and Lithuania to Warsaw and the rest of the European passenger network. Passenger services are provided by two rail service providers
column3: PKP Intercity that provides intercity passengers trains (express
column4: intercity
column6: hotel and TLK) and Przewozy Regionalne that operates only regional passenger trains financed by the voivodeship. Passenger trains are mostly run using electrical multiple units (on electrified lines) or rail buses.

column1: There is an extensive bus network that covers the entire city by three bus services
column2: but no tram or subway exists. The three bus operators (KPKM
column3: KPK and KZK) are owned by the city and each shares approximately a third of the lines and the bus fleet.

S8 /  E67: Budziska (Polish–Lithuania border) – Białystok – Warsaw – Wrocław – Kudowa-Zdrój (Czech–Polish border)
DW 675: Poleska Street and Tysiąclecia Państwa Polskiego StreetIn Białystok there are also Poviat roads which connect the city with other towns in the area:

column1: The municipal bicycle renting system is called BiKeR and was opened in 2014. System initially based on 30 stations equipped with 300 bikes. By 2018
column2: there were already over 130 km of bicycle paths in Bialystok. The city has four public bicycle repair stations
column3: in which one can fix their private bikes. The stations are located in places where the highest traffic of city bikes was observed.

column2: Białystok-Krywlany Airport
column3: lies within the city limits
column4: but does not provide regularly scheduled service. There were plans in 2011 to build a new regional airport
column6: that would have provided flights within Europe.

column1: Higher education in the city can be traced back to the second half of the eighteenth century
column2: when the ownership of the city was inherited by Field Crown Hetman Jan Klemens Branicki. As a patron of the arts and sciences
column3: Branicki encouraged numerous artists and scientists to settle in Białystok to take advantage of Branicki's patronage. In 1745 Branicki established Poland's first military college
column4: the School of Civil and Military Engineering
column5: in the city.Since the fall of communism many privately funded institutions of higher educations have been founded and their number is still increasing. Currently Białystok is home to one principal public university (University of Białystok) and two other public specialist universities (Białystok Technical University and Medical University of Białystok). Some institutions
column6: such as Musical Academy in Białystok
column7: are branches of their parent institutions in other cities
column8: usually in Warsaw.

column2: a number of people from Białystok have been prominent in the fields of science

column6: sports
column7: visual arts and performing arts. This environment was created in the mid eighteenth century by the patronage of Jan Klemens Branicki for the arts and sciences. These include Ryszard Kaczorowski
